event_registry_properties.name: action
event_registry_properties.item:
Schedule a repair procedure to replace the affected CPU, the identity of which can be determined using fmdump -v -u <EVENT-ID>.

The event-id can be found in the EVENT-ID field of the message.

For example:

    EVENT-ID: 4f5d5919-2da0-ef25-b2a2-d1c433f2f832
event_registry_properties.name: description
event_registry_properties.item: The number of errors associated with this CPU has exceeded acceptable levels.
event_registry_properties.name: details
event_registry_properties.item:
The Message ID:   %MSGID% indicates that the Solaris[TM] Fault Manager has received reports from a CPU that one or more errors associated with the Level 3 cache have been detected. The Diagnostic Engine (DE) has triggered an automatic response to disable and isolate this CPU from the configuration in order to prevent repeat errors and increase the system's total Availability.

Arrangements should be made to replace the Field Replaceable Unit (FRU) on which the suspect CPU is located. Refer to the information displayed in the FRU: field of the fmdump output.

For example: 


# fmdump -v -u 4f5d5919-2da0-ef25-b2a2-d1c433f2f832
TIME                 UUID                                 SUNW-MSG-ID
May 26 14:14:55.7126 4f5d5919-2da0-ef25-b2a2-d1c433f2f832 SUN4U-8001-0J
 100%  fault.cpu.ultraSPARC-IVplus.l3cachedata    
        FRU: hc:///component=SB16
       rsrc: mem:///component=SB16/P2/E0,J6400

In this example, the part to be replaced is the System Board in slot 16.

Sun Fire Midrange and High End notes:

There may be additional fault information logged by System Controller Application (ScApp) on Sun Fire[TM] Midrange (3800, 48x0, 6800, v1280, E2900, E4900, E6900) and System Management Services (SMS) on High End (12K, 15K, E20K, E25K) Servers. Availability enhancements (called AVL) have been integrated into ScApp 5.19.0 and SMS 1.5 to allow FMA/AVL interaction to coexist.
event_registry_properties.name: impact
po-action
event_registry_properties.item: Schedule a repair procedure to replace the affected CPU, the identity of which can be determined using fmdump -v -u <EVENT_ID>.
event_registry_properties.name: response
event_registry_properties.item: The fault manager will attempt to remove the affected CPU from service.
event_registry_properties.name: title
